title: Integration Studio—Atlassian Jira integration
content:
Overview

This topic presents an illustrated set of integration use cases between Service Management and Atlassian Jira:

  • Portal-based Defect or Enhancement requests 
  • Incident to Defect integration
  • Incident exchange

The use cases in a nutshell:

The integration use cases described in this document serve as examples to inspire and guide your integration efforts. However, they should not be considered as prescriptive or guaranteed solutions for your particular scenario. The examples may or may not be applicable for your license edition.
 The integration templates for defect and enhancement tracking are designed to work with Bug tracking projects in Jira.

Use case 1: Portal-based Defect or Enhancement requests

In this sample use case, end users who subscribe to a specific Business Service Application can report defects or request enhancements to the application by posting them via the Service Portal.

We will follow the steps below, which are performed by Eve, an employee who uses her company's eExpense application for expense tracking and reporting. She has been frustrated that expense reporting can only be done while logged on to the eExpense web application and wishes that her company would provide an enhancement to enable native mobile access for faster expense reporting. While Eve can post the enhancement request via the Portal, her company is tracking such application requests in a Jira system used by the application development team. However, the seamless integration with the Portal makes this internal detail transparent from Eve.

Step 1: Portal access

Eve logs on to the Service Portal where she knows she can have access to a variety of self-service support features, such as catalog, knowledge, and subscription management for the applications she uses every day.

Step 2:  Submitting an enhancement request or defect

Eve proceeds to get help from the Portal Virtual Agent, specifying that she would like to request an enhancement for eExpense. 

A second option is to raise an application defect or enhancement request is by leveraging her subscription. Below we see Eve consulting her list of Services & Assets where she can see her subscription to the eExpense application service listed.

She proceeds to drill down into the details of the application subscriptions and finds a list of requests she can make against the eExpense application. She selects the link to report an enhancement against the service. She could also use this method to raise a defect in case she needs to.

Another option is that Eve browses through the application category to find the offering to submit an enhancement request. 
In either case, the systems assist by providing her with a dedicated request form designed for the application service to either request an enhancement or report a defect.

Step 3: Jira enhancement created and confirmation provided back to the user

So far Eve has engaged purely via the Self-Service Portal. However, as soon as her request is submitted, a behind-the-scenes automation flow creates the necessary record in Jira. Below is a screen showing a Jira Issue record that has been created to track the request. Since Eve indicated that the issue type is "Improvement", the Jira record created has been appropriately tagged according to Jira's various issue types that can be used to track the development backlog.

Step 4: Status confirmation

While the record above is created behind the scenes, the Portal provides validation and confirmation back to Eve, letting her know that an enhancement record has been logged for review by the application development team. An enhancement ticket ID from Jira is even provided back to Eve so that she can use it for future reference.

Step 5: Behind the scenes - association of the Jira ticket from the Request ticket

While at this point the ownership of the enhancement has been passed over, we should also note that details of the association between the Jira Issue and Eve's Portal request have been logged. In reviewing the Request record, Service Desk agents can find a direct reference to the related Jira Issue that's tracking the potential work to enhance the application.

The screen below shows details about Jira's response in the creation of its Issue records as they are recorded in the Request's Offering section. Note some specific fields of interest, such as:

  • Remote ID: The Jira ID that's tracking the enhancement
  • Remote status: The status of the Jira record (at that point in time)
  • Remote system: The name of the system to integrate with
  • URL: A URL that takes the agent directly to the Jira issue for tracking

The creation of a defect in Jira can happen in the same way as raising an enhancement request. Select the "Report a defect" offering in the portal. The main difference is, the Enhancement request gets automatically resolved, but the defect stays open for analysis and troubleshooting by the helpdesk to answer questions from the application management team working with Jira.

Use case 2: Change request to enhancement

This use case describes how to create a new feature in Jira based on a Change request in Service Management. Within a change record, the change owner might want to create a new feature in Jira. To do so, the change owner can click the button Create Feature. The system will then create a new feature in Jira to track the requirement and put the details as external reference into the change record.

Use case 3: Incident/Request/Problem to defect

In this use case, Stephen reviews the Incident where a user reports an application malfunction. After analysis, Stephen confirms that the issue is an application defect, which needs to be fixed by the application team. 

Stephen assigns the ticket to the RnD group and enters a comment to the record. The assignment of the Incident triggers the execution of an integration, which creates a new defect in Jira.

 Incidents are used in this example. However, the defect creation into Jira can be triggered from Requests, Incidents, Problems, and Changes in Service Management. Triggering the integration from Studio apps requires some small changes to the integrations.

Tip: You can also create enhancement requests in Jira in a similar way.

After he clicks ADD & SAVE RECORD, the defect is created in Jira. Within the Incident in Service Management, we track the following data from the Jira record.

  • Remote ID: The Jira ID that's tracking the defect
  • Remote status: The status of the Jira record (at that point in time)
  • URL: A URL that takes the agent directly to the Jira Issue for tracking.

Clicking the URL in the Incident opens the record in Jira. The Incident details as well as the comments are transferred to the Jira system.

Use case 4: Incident to Incident

In this use case, an incident originating from Service Management is exchanged with Jira Service Management. This use case is similar to the defect tracking one, just that an incident is created in Jira instead of a defect.

Use case 5: Get status update

To get the latest status of the Jira record reflected in Service Management, a button Pull Update can be configured. Clicking the button will pull the status from Jira and update the record in Service Management. 

Example:

Let's change the status in the Jira defect we just raised:

Clicking the button in Service Management will show the new Jira status in the record.

In addition, a comment is added to the Discussions section.

Set up the integration

As an example, the procedure below will set up the integration to implement the Incident Exchange use case.

Prepare an integration user

Perform the following steps to prepare an integration user:

  1. Create an integration user. See How to create an integration user.

  2. Log in to the Agent Portal as the tenant admin, and do the following:

    • Navigate to Administration > Master Data > People, locate the integration user, and assign the proper roles to access the required modules. Example: Incident Manager, Incident Analyst, and Incident Coordinator. The user must also have a role with the On-Premise Bridge/Integration Administrator permission. 

      Alternatively, assign the Tenant Admin role to grant general access.

    • (If not Tenant Admin) Navigate to Administration > Master Data > People > Roles, and create a new role with Create, View, and Update permissions for the External reference and External system record types.

Export the certificate from the Jira instance

To connect to Jira, you will need to upload their root CA certificate in a later step. To get the certificate from Jira, you can export the certificate from the browser as base64 encoded to a file.

Configure an app in Jira (if you use OAuth 2.0 authentication)

If you use OAuth 2.0 to integrate with Jira, you must configure OAuth in the Jira developer console.

  1. Go to developer.atlassian.com.

  2. Select your profile icon in the top-right corner, and from the dropdown, select Developer console.

  3. Select your app from the list (or create one if you don't already have one).

  4. Select Authorization in the left menu.

  5. Click Configure next to OAuth 2.0 (3LO).

  6. Enter this value in the Callback URL field: https://<external_access_host>/rest/<tenant_id>/opb/oauth/callback.

    Where: <external_access_host> is the FQDN of your Service Management system.

    You can also copy the value of the Redirect URL field of the OAuth 2.0 endpoint that you will create for the integration.

  7. Click Save changes.

  8. Select Permissions in the left menu. You need to add permissions required by the integration on this form.

  9. Click Add next to Jira API.

  10. On the Classic scopes tab, click Edit Scopes.

  11. Select the checkbox before Create and manage issues (write:jira-work) and View Jira issue data (read:jira-work), and then click Save.

  12. Click the Granular scopes tab, and then click Edit Scopes.

  13. Search for scopes with the following codes, select the checkbox before the scopes, and then click Save: write:issue:jira, write:comment:jira, write:comment.property:jira, write:attachment:jira, read:issue:jira.

  14. Select Settings in the left pane.

  15. Copy Client ID and Secret in the Authentication details section. You will need to enter the information when you configure the OAuth 2.0 endpoint in Service Management.

Configure Service Management

Create an endpoint

Create an endpoint using the Rest Executor 2.0 endpoint type:

  1. Log in to the Agent Portal as the tenant admin.
  2. Navigate to Administration > Utilities > Integration > Endpoints.
  3. Click Add.
  4. Select Rest Executor 2.0 as the endpoint type, enter a name for the endpoint (for example, Jira), and then click Add. The system creates the endpoint.
  5. Click Configure and complete the fields depending on what authentication method to use and whether the endpoint needs to use the OPB Agent.
The Jira integration supports both basic authentication and OAuth 2.0 authentication. You can choose the authentication method according to your needs.

If the endpoint uses the Basic Authentication authentication method and doesn't use the OPB Agent, complete these fields.

Password

Enter the API token of the integration user of the Jira system.

This is not the user's password but instead the API token for the Jira user.

Certificate type Select X.509
Certificate format Select PEM

Enable email notification for token expiration

 If you want the Integration Studio to send notification emails to integration administrators when the Integration Studio's attempt to refresh the access token fails, select this checkbox.
Recipients Select the users who will receive email notifications for token expiration.

Get token configuration section

Grant Type

Select Authorization Code.

Client ID

Enter the Client ID you copied when configuring the app in Jira.

Client Secret

Enter the Secret you copied when configuring the app in Jira.

Authorization URL

Enter https://auth.atlassian.com/authorize?prompt=consent.

Redirect URL

This field is read-only.

You can copy the value of this field to the Callback URL field on the Authorization form when you configure the app in the Jira developer console.

Token URL

Enter https://auth.atlassian.com/oauth/token.

Scope

Enter the following codes: read:jira-work write:jira-work write:comment:jira write:comment.property:jira write:attachment:jira read:issue:jira offline_access.

State

Specify a value that is associated with the Jira user who must consent to the permissions for the Jira app you configured. This value can prevent malicious users from hijacking the authorization flow. For details, see the contents about the state parameter in the Jira documentation.

Send client Id and secret

 Select In body.

 This field is read-only.

Advanced options

Click Add, select Audience in the Key field, and then enter api.atlassian.com in the Value field.

Create an integration

Create an integration and configure one or more scenarios to define the business logic for forwarding tickets and synchronizing ticket updates to Jira. The Jira Software connector has three predefined scenario templates: 

  • Enhancement tracking
  • Defect tracking
  • Pull status updates

In the following steps, you'll create an integration with these predefined templates.

  1. Navigate to Administration > Utilities > Integration > Integration Studio.
  2. Click New, enter the name of your integration, and then click Save. The system displays the Integration page.
  3. In the Details section, configure the integration user you created for the current Service Management system and activate the integration.
  4. In the Connector-Endpoint mappings section, click Add to add a mapping.
  5. Select Jira (under Atlassian) as the connector, select the Jira endpoint that you created earlier, and then enter an alias for the mapping.
  6. Click Save.

Configure the scenarios

Perform the following steps to add the scenarios to the integration:

  1. Click Add scenario.
  2. Enter a name for the scenario. For example, Enhancement tracking.
  3. In the Template field, select Enhancement tracking (under Atlassian Jira) from the list.
  4. Click Save to add the scenario. 
  5. Repeat the steps above to add the rest of the scenarios listed in the table below.
 Using templates will make the integration configuration easier than starting from scratch. If you don't select this option, you'll have to manually add your own logic, starting from a blank page.

Use the following out-of-the-box scenarios for this integration. The following table describes the actions required for each of the scenarios before you run the integration. 

Scenario name

Actions required before using the scenario 
Enhancement tracking  In the Default parameters rule at the start of the process logic, enter the details:
  • Jira URL - The name of the Jira endpoint
  • Issue type - The type of the issue to create in Jira
  • Project - Your Jira project

Optional:

  • JiraInitialStatus
  • RemoteSystem
Defect tracking In the Default parameters rule at the start of the process logic, enter the details:
  • Jira URL - The name of the Jira endpoint
  • Issue type - The type of the issue to create in Jira
  • Project - your Jira project
Optional:
  • JiraInitialStatus
  • RemoteSystem
Incident to Incident

In the Settings rule at the start of the process logic, enter the details:

  • Jira URL - The name of the Jira endpoint 
  • RequestTypeId - The Id of the Request Type for the records to be created in Jira
  • ServiceDeskId - The ID of the Service Desk where the records are created

Optional:

  • JiraInitialStatus
  • RemoteSystem
  • Issue type
Pull status updates Optional:
  • RemoteSystem

Use the scenarios

Use case 1: Portal-based Defect or Enhancement requests

Having set up the endpoint and the integration, the final step is about the business logic to trigger the integration. To see this use case working, a Catalog Offering with a Fulfillment Task Plan that invokes the appropriate Jira integration is needed.

As you may recall, in the Use Case example, Eve submitted an Improvement Request via an Offering associated with the eExpense application:

In the newly created Offering:

  • We have designated Applications as a related Service Definition.
  • We have also set Subscription as the value for the Required asset information. This means that users submitting the Defect or Enhancement request for eExpense must have specified the Subscription to the Application service that they have been granted.

Specify user options

Specific user options will be added to collect information from the user as well as to store results provided back by Jira during its creation of an issue record. You can find the following options in the screens below:

User option name

Label

 Visibility Description
Title_c
 		 Provide a short title User A portal facing option used to collect the user's issue title
Description_c Provide a detailed description User A portal facing option used to collect the user's issue description
Success_c Record created? Agent Indicates whether the record was successfully created in the ALM system.

Define a task plan

In this step, create a task plan that triggers the Jira integration. The full task plan will include a few automated tasks as shown below:

  1. The first task creates the JIRA Issue. 
  2. A condition task then checks whether the Jira Issue was successfully created.
    • If it's a success, the subsequent tasks proceed to add a comment with results for the user and to mark the Request as fulfilled.
    • If it's a failure, a manual task is created which needs to be handled. The request stays in fulfilment queue for manual intervention.

Task 1: Create Enhancement in ALM System:

  1. Add an Automated Task.
  2. Give the task a title, description and assignment group.
  3. Select Call Integration Studio as the Business Rule for the Task.
  4. Select integration Jira and scenario Enhancement tracking.
  5. Save the task.

Decision details:

  1. Add a decision to the task plan.
  2. Enter a title.
  3. Enter following condition: ${entity.UserOptions.Success_c}.
  4. Enter Yes and No as output value.
  5. Save the task.

This decision waits that the Integration Studio updates the "Success" user option in the request with the integration result. The Integration Studio will set "Yes" in case of success or "No" in case of failure.

Task 2: Resolve Request

  1. Add an Automated Task.
  2. Give the task a title, description and assignment group.
  3. Select Set fields as the Business Rule for the Task.
  4. Enter a solution and a completion code.
  5. Save the task.

Task 3: Manually manage the request

  1. Add a manual Task.
  2. Give the task a title, description and assignment group.
  3. Save the task.

Define default value

In the default values section, define the values as required, but you must set at least a Service Desk group, a Service, and a Category to automatically move the request into the Initial Support phase, which then triggers the integration defined in the task plan.

In addition, set the "Record created?" user option to "pending response" since the Integration Studio is checking this initial value.

Save the offering.

Repeat the same steps for "Report a defect offering". The only difference is to select the Defect tracking scenario in the first task in the task plan and not add task 2 to automatically resolve the request.

To send additional comments from Service Management to Jira, add the following business rule to the Request entity in Studio.

The condition in this example is:

${current_update.Comments.IsChanged && current_user.Upn != '<UPN of the integration user>' && lookup('ExternalReference','RemoteSystem','EntityType','Request','EntityId',entity.Id,'RemoteSystem','Jira')=='Jira'}

This means when:

  • a comment is added
  • and the update is not coming from the integration user configured in the Integration Studio
  • and there is a Jira record in the ExternalReference entity

then the integration is triggered and comments are sent to Jira.

  1. Go to Studio and select the entity "change".

  2. Go to custom actions and add your custom action, make sure that you select the "Enable Workflow" checkbox.

Use case  3: Incident/Request/Problem to defect

To create defects directly from an incident, request, or problem, perform the following steps.

As the integration and endpoints are now set up, all you need to do is to create a business rule that triggers the integration based on your needs.

To do this, go to your studio entity > Processes and Rules > After applying changes, and then add a new "Call Integration Studio" business rule.

The condition in this example is:

${entity.ExpertGroup.Name=='RnD' && (current_update.ExpertGroup.IsChanged || current_update.Comments.IsChanged) && current_user.Upn != '<UPN of the integration user>'}

This means that the integration is triggered when:

  • the Incident is assigned to the RnD group as expert group
  • or a comment is added 
  • and the update is not coming from the integration user configured in the Integration Studio

You can add a similar business rule with your condition to trigger this integration.

It is also possible to create enhancement requests via this method.

Use case 4: Incident to Incident

To create incidents in Jira Service Management, perform the following steps.

As the integration and endpoint are now set up, all you need to do is to create a business rule that triggers the integration based on your needs.

To do this, go to your Studio entity > Processes and Rules > After applying changes, and then add a new "Call Integration Studio" business rule.

An example condition could be:

${entity.ExpertGroup.Name=='Jira' && (current_update.ExpertGroup.IsChanged || current_update.Comments.IsChanged) && current_user.Upn != '<UPN of the integration user>'}

This means that the integration is triggered when:

  • the Incident is assigned to the Jira group as expert group
  • or a comment is added 
  • and the update is not coming from the integration user configured in the Integration Studio

You can add a similar business rule with your condition to trigger this integration.
